results.title: Disney's best: the fabulous '50s
results.brief_description: Walt Disney and his staff of animators the 1950s were marked by transitions and experimentation, resulting in some of the most revolutionary cartoons ever released. The technique of “limited animation” and sylised design won “Toot, whistle, plunk and boom” the Academy Award for Best Cartoon Short Subject of 1953. Breakthrough results were also achieved in “Noah’s Ark”, which utilised stop-action photography and the animation of stick figures composed on pencils, cork and pipe cleaners. Titles included are: “Lambert, the sheepish lion” 1951, “Pigs is pigs” 1954, “Toot, whistle, plunk and boom” 1953, and “Noah’s Ark” 1959.

Breakthrough results were also achieved in “Noah’s Ark”, which utilised stop-action photography and the animation of stick figures composed on pencils, cork and pipe cleaners. Titles included are: “Lambert, the sheepish lion” 1951, “Pigs is pigs” 1954, “Toot, whistle, plunk and boom” 1953, and “Noah’s Ark” 1959.

results.title: Dishwashing by hand
results.creator_credit: Los Angeles City Health Department, Donald F. Grant and Dale W. Imus
results.brief_description: A film which emphasises the importance of hygienic dish-washing, showing that for health and attractive presentation in either large or small cafeterias, dishes must be scraped, pre-rinsed, washed, rinsed and drained. Both mechanical and hand methods are illustrated.

results.title: Discussion technique
results.creator_credit: United States. Dept. of the Army
results.brief_description: Shows how to conduct a discussion by forum, symposium, debate, panel, conference, and committee techniques; and how to stimulate independent thinking and free interchange of ideas among enlisted personnel.

results.title: Discussion
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Kindergarten child series”.
Intending to stimulate language development and curiosity, and enlargement of concepts, understanding, the teacher introduces some human vertebrae and discusses their relation to the human form, allowing the children to handle the bones. For preschool eduction.
